{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-43561].
  {panel}

h4. +Scenario+
If a workflow has an integrity problem, assigning it to a workflow scheme to be used by a project will make this a dead-end:
* the corrupted workflow does not work properly because of itself e.g. missing workflow buttons
* there's no way to switch to a different scheme or assigning a different workflow to replace the corrupted one because of publishing/associating failure:
{noformat}
Technical details
Log's referral number: 7ff20bca-f7b0-46f2-8bc8-82a1c69ddf74

h4. +Steps to reproduce+
# export a working workflow to XML e.g. Classic Default Workflow
# open the XML file and look for an entry like this:
{code}<step id="1" name="Open">
      <meta name="jira.status.id">1</meta>{code}
# remove the meta value, so it becomes:
{code}<step id="1" name="Open">
      <meta name="jira.status.id"></meta>{code}
# save the XML file and import it into JIRA with a unique name
# open the imported workflow and notice that step Open has NO linked Status:
!corrupt.png|thumbnail!
# simply assign it to a workflow scheme used by a project, so that both the workflow and workflow scheme are *active*
# create a new issue in the project that will use this corrupted workflow
# attempt to switch the project's workflow scheme or assign a new workflow to the scheme and publish it
-> 500 Error Page

h4. +Suggestion+
{panel}Since customers might rely on XML to prepare and import workflows, which are susceptible to errors, there should be a validation step when adding a workflow to a workflow scheme that should be able to detect whether the to-be-added workflow has an integrity problem or not, so that a dead-end like described above won't happen.{panel}

h4. +Note+
Currently when adding a corrupted workflow like described above, this kind of diagram is seen, which is not clear whether it has an integrity problem in it:
!classic.png|thumbnail!

h4. +Workaround+
# From the UI, make a copy of the corrupted workflow and edit it properly
# (!) Take an XML backup of JIRA if necessary
# Shut down JIRA
# (!) Take an SQL backup of the database if necessary
# Run this SQL query to identify the relationship between project, workflow, and issue type (replace DUMMY with the respective project key of the project with the corrupted workflow):
{code}SELECT 
    p.pname as 'Project Name',
    p.pkey as 'Project Key',
    wse.id as 'Entity ID',
    wse.scheme as 'Workflow Scheme ID',
    ws.name as 'Workflow Scheme Name',
    wse.workflow as 'Workflow Name',
    wse.issuetype as 'Issue Type'
FROM
    workflowschemeentity wse inner join workflowscheme ws on wse.scheme = ws.id
    inner join nodeassociation na on ws.id = na.sink_node_id
    inner join project p on p.id = na.source_node_id
WHERE
    p.pkey = 'DUMMY' and na.sink_node_entity = 'WorkflowScheme';{code}
(i) Sample result:
|Project Name	|Project Key	|Entity ID	|Workflow Scheme ID	|Workflow Scheme Name	|Workflow Name	|Issue Type|
|Dummy Project	|DUMMY	|10900	|10700	|Dummy Workflow Scheme	|Dummy Workflow	|0|
{panel}
(/) In this example, Dummy Workflow is the corrupted workflow. The workaround is to associate the copied/edited workflow of Dummy Workflow to Dummy Workflow Scheme via an SQL query. Take note of the Entity ID above, which is 10900 in this example.
(!) There may be more rows returned, in case the project uses multiple workflows for multiple issue types, so just take note of the Entity ID of the corrupted workflow in your case.
{panel}
# Let's say the copied/edited workflow (in step 1) is named 'Edited Dummy Workflow', run this SQL query to make sure it exists in the database:
{code}SELECT id, workflowname FROM jiraworkflows WHERE workflowname = 'Edited Dummy Workflow';{code}
# If it exists, then run this SQL query to associate it to Dummy Workflow Scheme as discussed above:
{code}
UPDATE workflowschemeentity SET workflow = 'Edited Dummy Workflow' WHERE id = 10900;
{code}
(i) replace 10900 with the Entity ID identified in your case
# Restart JIRA
(/) project DUMMY should be using Edited Dummy Workflow instead of Dummy Workflow now, which is possible to be edited if necessary.
fields.summary: Validate workflow integrity before allowing addition to workflow scheme

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

When you change the JIRA instance Default language from the default English to Czech (but tested also for German, for example) and you create a new project afterwards, the are new, and seemingly unwanted, Issue Types and Resolutions generated - duplicating the existing ones. See the attached screenshots for an illustration.

One can imagine all the drawbacks connected with this. One of the problems is that the newly generated Issue Types lack translations -> so you must (re)translate them to English and so on if needed.

Tested on JIRA 6.4.4, with just the Agile add-on installed.

The simplest way of how to work-around this issue (or an undocumented feature?) is NOT to switch from the default English language, which is also the best usage scenario in the most cases... :)

  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
When a mail server is using AES_256 ciphers, JIRA is unable to connect to it with the following error
{code}Unfortunately no connection was possible. Review the errors below and rectify:
EOFException: SSL peer shut down incorrectly{code}

OpenSSL is able to connect to the Mail Server from the JIRA host server using JIRA credentials, but JIRA itself isn't able to.

Using SSL dump, the main difference is that for the working connection (using OpenSSL), AES_128 & AES_256 ciphers are offered, with TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA being accepted. For the JIRA initiated IMAPS connection, only AES_128 ciphers are offered, which the mailserver rejects straight away.

The following are SSL dump extraces from JIRA and OpenSSL
* [^JIRA.txt]
* [^OpenSSL.txt]
fields.summary: Support integration with applications using AES_256 encryption

fields.description:
I was performing a manual upgrade following instructions from the following page:
[https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA064/Upgrading+JIRA+Manually#UpgradingJIRAManually-3.SettingupyournewJIRAinstallation ]

There were a few sections which were a little unclear and perhaps could be reworded or updated.

Section 2.3 -
{quote}3. Navigate to the directory specified in the configuration file and create a backup of it in another directory.
4. (error) Delete the file <jira-home>/dbconfig.xml as soon as the backup is complete.{quote}

It's unclear whether the file has to be deleted from the back up or the original folder.  This makes a difference when performing Step 3.2.  It should be clearer that it the file should be removed from the original folder.

{quote}3.2 Point your new JIRA to (a copy of) your existing JIRA Home directory
If your new JIRA 6.4 installation is on a new server, copy the backup of your existing JIRA Home Directory from the old server to the new server before proceeding.{quote}

The user needs to be instructed to keep a backup of the folder and if they are moving to a new server to use a copy of the original folder (which should be minus the dbconfig file).

{quote}3.6 Import your old JIRA data into your new JIRA
After you have started your new JIRA installation, import the data from your old instance into the new instance. You will need the backup file of data from your old JIRA that you created earlier in these instructions (above).

To import your old JIRA data into your new JIRA:

Log in as a user with the 'JIRA System Administrators' global permission.{quote}
After JIRA has been restarted, the user will be directed to the startup wizard - which asks users to set up a new jira instance, or back up from XML.  In order to follow the rest of the instructions the user needs to set up a clean version of JIRA.  This should be mentioned after {quote}After you have started your new JIRA installation,{quote}, to save confusion, or the customer importing the XML twice.
fields.summary: Upgrading JIRA Manually Instructions update suggestions

fields.description:

Specifying a value of 0 (i.e. zero, which is the default value) for this property disables this feature."

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-43494].
  {panel}

(This is a suggestion for the JIRA dev teams.)

From an operations point of view, if a process is not logging anything, it may be broken. 
So if a long running JIRA upgrade doesn't emit a message for more than 30s or so, then JIRA administrators may well think that the upgrade has failed. I've been seeing upgrades that just go silent for minutes at a time, and it makes them harder than necessary

As a suggested guideline, any upgrade task that has a loop in it should do the following:

1.  Log a message that the task is about to start processing and also log the number of items to process
2.. Log a message every 1% or 5% of items that are completed, aiming for a message every 30s or so
3.  Log a message when the task is completed with the number of items and total duration (this seems to be done already in most upgrade tasks)

#2 would be a big improvement for all JIRA upgrades

This came up in the context of JRA-34394 and a 6.2.7 to 6.4.4 upgrade
fields.summary: Upgrade tasks  - code review suggestion

fields.description:
Use case:

A customer asked me which version of Java to use with JIRA 6.4.4. I said the only way to know what Atlassian was using was to run the Linux or Windows installer. They asked me to find out without running the installer (https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/15833150/how-to-find-the-jre-version-in-the-jira-installer) but I was not able to.

The documentation currently just says use a version >= Java 1.8.0_40
But the exact version that is shipped with the JIRA installer is not documented anywhere

Suggestion: add the JVM version README,txt file that is already shipped with the JIRA server tar.gz packages. It looks like the JIRA version is already added there by the JIRA build/release process

  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
At the moment, it's not possible to attach a file to JIRA when the file name contains restricted characters: {{'\', '/','\"', '%', ':', '$', '?', '*'}} (as per the documentation: [Attaching a File|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Attaching+a+File#AttachingaFile-AttachingaFiletoanIssue]). When a user attempts to upload a file with an incorrect name, they get an error message, then need to cancel the operation, get back to the file system, rename the file, get back to JIRA and attach it again. This can lead to a lot wasted time, especially when files are created and named automatically, e.g. in case of screenshots in Ubuntu.

h3. Suggested Solution
There should be an option to automatically sanitize the file name by removing the offending characters, and proceed with attaching the file right away.
fields.summary: Automatically Remove Special Characters From Attachment Filenames

      at com.atlassian.jira.task.ForkedThreadExecutor$ForkedRunnableDecorator.run(ForkedThreadExecutor.java:254)
      at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
{noformat}

*Note:*
* The problem doesn't occur when importing the custom date on the CSV into the default "Created Date" or "Resolution Date" fields.
* The error also happens if using a saved configuration .txt instead of manually setting the date.

*Workaround:*
* On the "Look and Feel" configuration section, revert "Complete Date/Time Format" settings before importing. It can be set back again after the import completes.
fields.summary: Invalid date format error when importing CSV DateTime fields with custom date format

*Summary*
Could not close tickets as the user didn't have the transition issue permission.
Didn't also get any notification from the Permission Helper nor Workflow to show that he lacked a specific permission.

Would appreciate if interdependent permissions are checked when a user runs permission helper that shows a warning that they do not have a dependent permission to achieve the permission they are verifying.

*Steps to Reproduce*
- Remove a user from transition permission in JIRA.
-* Ensure the user has Close Issue Permission.
- Attempt to close issue which the user has permission for.
-* Result: You would not have the close button hence cannot close the issue*
- Checking the Close Issue permission with permission helper would show that you have the needed permission to close the issue without showing that the dependent transition issue permission is missing which can be misleading.

*Moving Forward*
- Add a check to all dependent permissions that shows that a user does not have a permission to do a specific action because they are lacking the dependent permission and then return a warning to the customer telling them they lack that permission.
fields.summary: Allow Permission Helper show missing dependent Permissions

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

  {panel}

h3. Symptoms

When using the [Database Integrity Checker|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Using+the+Database+Integrity+Checker] a stack trace is generated.

The following may be found within the {{atlassian-jira.log}}:

{noformat:borderStyle=solid| borderColor=#6A8EB3 |bgColor=#F8F8F8}

com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.exception.IntegrityException: Error occurred while performing check.
	at com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.check.WorkflowCurrentStepCheck.doCheck(WorkflowCurrentStepCheck.java:167)
	at com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.check.WorkflowCurrentStepCheck.preview(WorkflowCurrentStepCheck.java:54)
	at com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.IntegrityChecker.preview(IntegrityChecker.java:63)
	at com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.IntegrityChecker.previewWithIds(IntegrityChecker.java:35)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.IntegrityChecker.doExecute(IntegrityChecker.java:71)
	...
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.jira.workflow.DefaultWorkflowSchemeManager.getSchemeForProject(DefaultWorkflowSchemeManager.java:382)
	at com.atlassian.jira.workflow.DefaultWorkflowSchemeManager.getWorkflowName(DefaultWorkflowSchemeManager.java:350)
	at com.atlassian.jira.workflow.OSWorkflowManager.getWorkflowName(OSWorkflowManager.java:166)
	at com.atlassian.jira.workflow.OSWorkflowManager.getWorkflow(OSWorkflowManager.java:554)
	at com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.check.WorkflowCurrentStepCheck.doCheck(WorkflowCurrentStepCheck.java:111)
	...

{noformat}
h3. Cause

This is caused by an issue row in the {{jiraissue}} table that referred to a project id for a Project that no longer exists in the database. 

h3. Workaround

# Run the "Check Issue for Relation 'RelatedOSWorkflowEntry'" check first;
# Fix any entries that are returned;
# At this point the complete test can be run.

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-43462].
  {panel}

The following suggestion is provide for your/my amusement, I don't seriously think it will get through but if it does it would be sweet.

The new feature is to have some kind of scoring system for users, where performing some action allocates points to the user.

e.g. 
- closing an issue within x days = +1 point 
- logging an issue that has already been solved in another JIRA ticket = -5000 points
- logging an issue that has already been answered in a confluence page = -5000 points
- logging an incomplete issue = -50000 points
- logging an issue as urgent, then when feedback is requested, take x days to respond = -500000 points
- logging an issue as urgent, then when it is fixed, take x days to test it = -5000000 points
- emailing JIRA without removing your signature, thereby adding a thousand attachments I have to then remove for you = -500000000000000 points

You could use this point system to allow you rank /  prioritize issues that are reported 
e.g. Bob has 500 points, Sue has -5000 points, Bobs issue gets looked at before Sue's

You could put a flag on the users avatar based on their points level

Points could unlock certain cool features e.g. animated GIF avatars

I'm sure others can think of ways to expand on this...
fields.summary: User ranking / scoring system

h4. Problem Definition

Currently any user with browse users permission is able to mention any user in an issue or comment. 

For use-cases where admins may not want members of a particular project to be able to see users restricted to another project (e.g. project a for customer a, and project b for customer b), it may be useful to limit user suggestions when using the @mention to mention users in comments or issues to users having browse project permissions.

h5. Summary:
If a user has set reporter to receive notification for when issues are created and when issues are commented(so they can get notification when others comment on their issues). If they set "Don't notify Me" in their {{profile > preference> My Changes}}.
They do not get any notification at all of changes they make, including a notification if they create an issue.
If they Set the option to "Notify Me", they get all updates of changes including those from their own comments.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-43448].
  {panel}

Given that during a transition, users dynamically upload attachments, and then type a comment, what results is a 'spread' of attachment creation times, potentially many minutes apart, making identification of them difficult as being 'related' the user action / transition that resulted in an IssueEvent.

So, with a user uploading the odd file, having a coffee, and thinking long and hard about the related comment, the Event Listener has no real idea of what attachments were stored as part of that transition. It would be reasonable (I thought) to assume that any attachment added within the last N seconds to the corresponding issue would be related to the current event, however, given the spread above, its not possible to 'tightly' identify by attachment creation time, which were created 'most likely' by the current event.

Is there a reason that the attachment creation timestamp reflects the point at which they were uploaded, rather than when the user hits submit on the transition screen?

Ideally, all attachments uploaded would have the same timestamp of the point at which the transition screen Submit occurred?

Alternatively, it would be super-useful for the transition related variables to be available in issue events, which they currently aren't.
fields.summary: When attachments are uploaded as part of a transition they get the upload timestamp as their creation date

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-43405].
  {panel}

*To Reproduce:*
Set com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.providers to DEBUG to see how JIRA converts JQL into Lucene queries.

Create two issues with summaries:
Placer One: MBL-RFT-00063
Placer One: MBL-RFTO-000045
*MBL-*
Search in navigator:
summary ~ "\"Placer One: MBL-*\""
Converted Lucene query:
+pq_support_summary:"Placer One MBL"

*Results:*
As you can see above, JIRA actually removes the Wildcard character when generating the Lucene query.
The removal of the Wildcard character makes sense because Lucene does not support wild card searches for phrases. See [official lucene documentation|http://lucene.apache.org/core/3_3_0/queryparsersyntax.html] for reference.

- Wildcard Searches
Lucene supports single and multiple character wildcard searches within single terms (not within phrase queries).

When you put \" \" it forces JIRA to convert the search as a phrase, instead of individual terms. The phrase "Placer One: MBL" matches the ticket's summary. 

*MBL-R*
Search in navigator:
summary ~ "\"Placer One: MBL-R*\""

*Converted Lucene query:*
+pq_support_summary:"Placer One MBL R"

Again, notice how JIRA removes the wildcard character as its not supported.
This search fails because the phrase "Placer One MBL R" doesn't match the ticket summary. (that extra a without the -!)

*Workaround:*
One workaround is to search on a per-term basis (so wild cards can be used) instead of searching with an entire phrase. So you need to remove the escaped inverted commas. 
Here's some sample JQL that successfully returns the issues:
summary ~ "Placer One MBL R*"
summary ~ "Placer One MBL RT*"
summary ~ "Placer One M* R*"
summary ~ "Placer One M*  RFT*"

*Notice how removing the \" \" from the search tells Lucene to search on a per-term basis, allowing us to use the trailing wildcard characters.*

*Suggestion:*
This is fixed in [Lucene 4.8.0|https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LUCENE-1486] JIRA 6.4 is on Lucene 3.3.0. In future versions use 4.8.0 to allow for more dynamic search functions with JQL.
fields.summary: Wildcards not supported in phrases.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-43397].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Replying to a JIRA issue email without the issue key in the subject results in a new ticket being created as the 'In-Reply-To' value is not being parsed correctly.


h3. Environment
Cloud
Server



h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Send an email to JIRA
# Forward the confirmation email to another email address
# Remove the issue key from the subject line and reply to all


h3. Expected Results
JIRA should parse the 'In-Reply-To' line within the message header and match it to the existing ticket


h3. Actual Results
JIRA opens a new ticket

What is seen is that the current versions of JIRA Server generates email notifications with mail headers such as:

{noformat}
Message-ID: <398968471.2.1431682003072.JavaMail.andy@dev-jira>
In-Reply-To: <JIRA.12400.1431681970000@Atlassian.JIRA>
References: <JIRA.12400.1431681970000@Atlassian.JIRA> <JIRA.12400.1431681970299@dev-jira>
{noformat}

When a reply is sent the headers are included, and used by the standard JIRA mail handlers (amongst others) 

[MailThreadManager|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/javadoc/jira/6.4/reference/com/atlassian/jira/mail/MailThreadManager.html]

however, in the method:

{code:java}
private Issue parseIssueFromMessageId(final String messageId)
{code}

An example In-Reply-To header value of:
{noformat}
<JIRA.12400.1431681970000@Atlassian.JIRA>
{noformat}

Is split based on . into:
{noformat}
[<JIRA, 12400, 1431681970000@Atlassian, JIRA>]
{noformat}

The method above tries to parse \[2] which is '1431681970000@Atlassian' into a Long which throws a RuntimeException.

h3.Workaround
Ensure that the issue key is referenced in the subject line of the email	

h3. Notes:
This can also Happen intermittently
fields.summary: In-Reply-To processing is broken - header not being parsed correctly

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-43394].
  {panel}

JIRA's current behavior is to hide fields that has empty (null) value. The purpose is to prevent those fields to clutter the issue view screen. However, some fields need a permanent visibility even though it is empty, as it will need to be added in the later stage/status.

Therefore, allow options to enforce Custom Field visibility in the issue view screen, through the Field Configuration page.

h3. Workaround
Add a *Default Value* into the custom field in the *Field Configuration* page, to enforce its visibility
fields.summary: Allow options to enforce Custom Field visibility in the Issue View screen

Steps to reproduce:

1. setup project with annonymous access allowed (set browse project permission for anyone in project)
2. create an issue
3. as anonymous go to issue search view (/issues)
4. select list view
5. add new column

Expected result:
Column is added to visible columns list.

Actual result:

  {panel}

h3. Summary
Currently, there is no clear documentation of the configuration of JIRA Data Center clusters with respect to the use of multicast used between nodes, this information should be disclosed in the documentation to make the product more serviceable.

h3. Expected Results
There should be some documentation regarding Multicasting communicated in and throughout the documentation of the JIRA Data Center product.

h3. Actual Results
No clear documentation currently exists.

h3. Notes
JIRA Data Center allows (at least) the configuration of the following [ehcache|http://ehcache.org/] properties with regards to UDP multicasting:

* ehcache.multicast.timeToLive

* ehcache.listener.hostName

* ehcache.listener.port

* ehcache.multicast.address

* ehcache.multicast.port
fields.summary: JIRA Data Center needs documentation on Multicast UDP Configuration
Allow search by matching values in fields
Information regarding condition to close issue

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-43373].
  {panel}

This is similar to JRA-28436, but that item has been Closed.

My company purchased Zephyr for JIRA to enable test case management within JIRA, but I have noticed this has created some instances where the data is not helpful.

Our Directors are now looking to the Road Map feature to show progress on the version of various projects. The problem that arises if we have all the Test issue types included in the totals for a version. So if a version has 20 Development Tasks that are resolved and 200 Tests that are left open for regression testing, the 200 Tests are causing the number of unresolved items to go way beyond where it actually is.

To have the ability to remove certain issue types would greatly benefit us.
fields.summary: Filter Issue Types out of Road Map
Ability to prevent closing an issue if all linked "is blocked by" issues are not closed

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-43368].
  {panel}

h4. Current scenario:
'Assignee' field cannot be set as required on Field Configuration. The only option to have assignee required is upon changing the "Allow unassigned issues" setting under General Configuration, which affects all projects. 

h4. Work-around:
Assignee field can be marked as required upon using a 3rd party add-on, as per steps listed on [this|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Making+'Assignee'+field+required+when+'Allow+unassigned+issues'+is+turned+ON+in+General+Configuration] article.

h4. Suggestion:
Allow "Assignee" field to be set as required on Field Configuration schemes, like any other field.
fields.summary: Allow 'Assignee' field to be required when 'Allow unassigned issues' is turned ON in General Configuration
